name: Digital Battery Passport
description: A digital record accessible via QR code containing detailed information about the battery's composition, carbon footprint, supply chain, performance, and circularity. Must include ~80 mandatory data attributes across seven clusters.

name: Carbon Footprint Declaration — EV Batteries
description: EV battery manufacturers must declare the carbon footprint of their batteries using the Product Environmental Footprint (PEF) methodology, covering cradle-to-grave lifecycle excluding the use phase.
plainLanguage: You must calculate and publicly declare the carbon footprint of each EV battery model you place on the market, using the EU’s standardised calculation method (PEF). This is already in effect.
dataRequirements: Lifecycle GHG emissions (kg CO2e per kWh)
PEF-compliant calculation methodology
Carbon footprint per functional unit (kg CO2e per kWh of total energy provided over expected lifetime)

Data quality requirements: primary data for cathode active material, cell manufacturing energy

name: Carbon Footprint Declaration — Industrial Batteries

plainLanguage: You must calculate and declare the carbon footprint for each industrial rechargeable battery model above 2 kWh that you place on the EU market.

name: Carbon Footprint Declaration — LMT Batteries
description: Light means of transport (LMT) batteries must include a carbon footprint declaration from August 2028.
plainLanguage: You must calculate and declare the carbon footprint for each LMT battery model (e-bikes, e-scooters) you place on the EU market.

name: Carbon Footprint Performance Classes — EV Batteries
description: EV batteries must be assigned a carbon footprint performance class based on the statistical distribution of declared carbon footprint values.
plainLanguage: Each EV battery model will receive a performance class rating (like an energy label) based on how its carbon footprint compares to other batteries on the market.

name: Carbon Footprint Performance Classes — Industrial Batteries
description: Industrial rechargeable batteries above 2 kWh must be assigned a carbon footprint performance class.
plainLanguage: Each industrial rechargeable battery model above 2 kWh will receive a performance class rating based on how its carbon footprint compares to other batteries on the market.
dataRequirements: Carbon footprint declaration (prerequisite)

Carbon footprint performance class (A through E)

name: Carbon Footprint Maximum Thresholds — EV Batteries
description: EV batteries exceeding a maximum carbon footprint threshold will be prohibited from being placed on the EU market.
plainLanguage: There will be an upper limit on how much CO2 an EV battery can generate over its lifecycle. Batteries exceeding this limit cannot be sold in the EU.

name: Recycled Content Documentation
description: Manufacturers must document and declare the share of recycled cobalt, lead, lithium, and nickel in their batteries.
plainLanguage: You must track and declare what percentage of key materials (cobalt, lead, lithium, nickel) in your batteries comes from recycled sources.

name: Performance & Durability Information
description: Technical documentation on battery performance and durability must accompany industrial, LMT, and EV batteries placed on the EU market.
plainLanguage: You must provide detailed technical information about your battery's performance characteristics and expected lifetime, including rated capacity, cycle life, and energy efficiency.

name: Supply Chain Due Diligence
description: All economic operators placing batteries on the EU market must establish due diligence policies for raw material sourcing, covering human rights, environmental risks, and conflict minerals. Postponed from August 2025 to August 2027 via Omnibus IV.
plainLanguage: You must implement and publicly communicate a responsible sourcing policy covering risks like child labour, forced labour, and environmental harm in your battery supply chain. Annual third-party audits and public reporting are required.
dataRequirements: Due diligence policy document
Supply chain mapping for cobalt, lithium, nickel, natural graphite

Auditor accreditation details and audit scope

name: QR Code & Data Carrier
description: All batteries placed on the EU market must bear a QR code linking to prescribed information. The QR code must be physically affixed and remain readable throughout the battery's lifetime.
plainLanguage: Every battery you sell in the EU must have a QR code printed or affixed on it that links to information about the battery (basic info for all batteries, full passport data for EV/LMT/industrial >2kWh).

Unique product identifier encoded

name: CE Marking & EU Declaration of Conformity
description: All batteries placed on the EU market must bear CE marking and be accompanied by an EU Declaration of Conformity.
plainLanguage: Your batteries must carry the CE mark and you must have a formal EU Declaration of Conformity document confirming your battery meets all applicable EU requirements. This is already in effect.

name: Labelling Requirements
description: Batteries must bear specific labels including manufacturer information, battery type, chemistry, hazardous substances, and separate collection symbol. Requirements phase in from August 2024 with additional requirements from February 2026.
plainLanguage: Your batteries must carry specific labels with manufacturer details, battery chemistry, hazardous substance warnings, and recycling symbols. Some labels are already required; additional labelling requirements kick in from February 2026.

name: Safety Requirements (SBESS)
requirement: Safety Requirements for Stationary Energy Storage (Article 12)
description: Stationary battery energy storage systems must meet specific safety requirements and documentation standards.
plainLanguage: If you manufacture or import stationary battery energy storage systems, they must meet additional safety requirements and be accompanied by safety documentation. This is already in effect.

name: Collection Targets -- Portable Batteries
requirement: Collection Rate Targets for Portable Batteries (Articles 55-59)
description: Producers (manufacturers/importers) of portable batteries must achieve minimum collection rates: 45% by end of 2023, 63% by end of 2027, and 73% by end of 2030, calculated as a percentage of the average weight of portable batteries sold in the preceding three calendar years.
plainLanguage: If you manufacture or import portable batteries sold in the EU, you must collect (via take-back schemes) a minimum percentage of the weight of batteries you have sold. The 63% target takes effect at end of 2027, rising to 73% by end of 2030.
dataRequirements: Weight of portable batteries placed on market (per calendar year)
Weight of waste portable batteries collected (per calendar year)
Collection rate calculation (3-year rolling average)
Producer registration in each member state
Collection scheme membership or individual scheme approval
Annual reporting to competent authorities

name: Collection Targets -- LMT Batteries
requirement: Collection Rate Targets for LMT Batteries (Articles 55-59)
description: Producers of LMT batteries must achieve minimum collection rates of 51% by end of 2028 and 61% by end of 2031, calculated as a percentage of the average weight of LMT batteries sold in the preceding three calendar years.
plainLanguage: If you manufacture or import LMT batteries (e-bikes, e-scooters) sold in the EU, you must collect a minimum percentage of the weight of batteries you have sold. The first target of 51% applies from end of 2028.
dataRequirements: Weight of LMT batteries placed on market (per calendar year)
Weight of waste LMT batteries collected (per calendar year)
Collection rate calculation (3-year rolling average)

Collection scheme membership or individual scheme approval
Annual reporting to competent authorities

name: Recycling Efficiency Targets
description: Recyclers of waste batteries must achieve minimum recycling efficiency rates by chemistry type: lead-acid 75% (by 31 Dec 2025, rising to 80% by 31 Dec 2030), lithium-based 65% (by 31 Dec 2025, rising to 70% by 31 Dec 2030), nickel-cadmium 80%, and other 50%. Material recovery minimums apply for cobalt (16% by 2027, 26% by 2031), copper (90%), lead (90%), lithium (50% by 2027, 80% by 2031), and nickel (90% by 2027, 95% by 2031).
plainLanguage: If you operate a battery recycling facility processing EU waste batteries, you must meet minimum recycling efficiency targets by chemistry type and recover minimum amounts of cobalt, lithium, nickel, copper, and lead from waste batteries.
dataRequirements: Recycling efficiency rate by battery chemistry (%)
Material recovery rate for cobalt (%)

name: Recycled Content Minimum Levels
description: Batteries containing cobalt, lead, lithium, or nickel in active materials must meet minimum recycled content levels. Phase 1 (18 August 2031): Co 16%, Pb 85%, Li 6%, Ni 6%. Phase 2 (18 August 2036): Co 26%, Li 12%, Ni 15%. Applies to industrial batteries >2kWh, EV batteries, SLI batteries, and LMT batteries.
plainLanguage: From August 2031, your batteries must contain minimum percentages of recycled cobalt, lead, lithium, and nickel. These minimum thresholds increase further in 2036. This is separate from the documentation obligation (already in Art 8 from August 2028).
dataRequirements: Recycled cobalt content in active material (%)
Recycled lead content in battery (%)
Recycled lithium content in active material (%)
Recycled nickel content in active material (%)

Calculation methodology per delegated act

name: Battery Management System Data Access
requirement: BMS Data Access for Independent Operators (Article 14)
description: EV and industrial batteries with a battery management system (BMS) must provide read-only access to real-time and historical data to independent operators (repairers, remanufacturers, second-life preparers) and the vehicle/appliance owner. Data includes state of charge, state of health, remaining capacity/power, and usage history.
plainLanguage: If your EV or industrial battery has a BMS, you must enable independent repair shops, remanufacturers, and battery owners to access real-time data from the BMS. This supports repair, reuse, and second-life applications.
dataRequirements: BMS read-only data access interface specification

name: Removability of Portable Batteries
requirement: End-User Removability of Portable Batteries in Appliances (Article 11)
description: Portable batteries incorporated in appliances must be readily removable and replaceable by the end user at any time during the lifetime of the appliance. Manufacturers of appliances must design products to allow easy battery removal using commonly available tools and without risk of damage. Exemptions exist for safety, water/dust protection, and data integrity reasons (with conditions).
plainLanguage: If you make appliances containing portable batteries, those batteries must be designed so the end user can easily remove and replace them. Limited exemptions apply (e.g., waterproofing, professional medical devices).
dataRequirements: Design documentation demonstrating end-user removability
Instructions for battery removal and replacement

Justification document if exemption claimed
Replacement battery availability commitment

name: Hazardous Substance Restrictions
requirement: Restrictions on Hazardous Substances (Article 6, Annex I)
description: Batteries placed on the EU market must comply with substance restrictions: mercury <0.0005% by weight in all batteries, cadmium <0.002% by weight in portable batteries (with SLI and specific industrial exemptions), and lead <0.01% by weight in portable batteries (subject to REACH restrictions). The Commission may adopt further restrictions based on REACH evaluations.
plainLanguage: Your batteries must not exceed EU limits for mercury, cadmium, and lead content. These limits are already in effect. Additional substance restrictions may be added through future delegated acts.
dataRequirements: Mercury content declaration (% by weight)
Cadmium content declaration (% by weight)
Lead content declaration (% by weight)
Full bill of materials with substance concentrations
Supplier declarations of hazardous substance compliance
Test reports from accredited laboratory

name: Battery Producer Registration
description: Producers (manufacturers or importers who place batteries on the market under their own name/trademark, or who first make batteries available in a member state) must register in the national producer register of each member state before placing batteries on that market. Registration must include producer identity, battery types, brand names, and compliance scheme information.
plainLanguage: Before you sell batteries in any EU member state, you must register as a battery producer in that country's national register. This applies to manufacturers, importers, and brands selling under their own name.
dataRequirements: Producer name, address, contact details
National registration number (per member state)
Battery types placed on market (portable, LMT, SLI, industrial, EV)
Battery brand names and trademarks

Collection/take-back scheme membership details
Annual reporting of batteries placed on market (weight and number)

name: Waste Battery Treatment Standards
requirement: Treatment and Recycling of Waste Batteries (Article 70)
description: Waste batteries must be treated and recycled at facilities that meet the best available techniques (BAT) and applicable EU health, safety, and environmental standards. Treatment must include removal of all fluids and acids. Facilities must hold permits. Battery producers bear the financial responsibility for collection, treatment, and recycling of waste batteries.
plainLanguage: If you are a battery producer in the EU, you are financially responsible for ensuring waste batteries are properly treated and recycled at permitted facilities meeting EU standards. This includes portable, industrial, EV, and all other battery types.
dataRequirements: Waste battery treatment contracts with permitted facilities
Treatment facility permits and certifications
Treatment process documentation
Annual volumes of waste batteries treated (by chemistry)
Financial guarantee or insurance for end-of-life obligations
Compliance with Annex XII recycling efficiency targets

name: SCIP Database Notification (SVHC Articles)
regulation: Waste Framework Directive 2008/98/EC (as amended by Directive (EU) 2018/851)
requirement: SCIP Database Notification for Articles Containing SVHCs (Art 9(1)(i) WFD)
description: Suppliers of articles containing Candidate List substances (SVHCs) above 0.1% weight by weight must submit a notification to the SCIP (Substances of Concern In articles as such or in complex objects — Products) database maintained by ECHA. The notification must be made before or at the time the article is placed on the EU market. SCIP is mandated by the Waste Framework Directive to ensure substance information is available throughout the waste lifecycle.
plainLanguage: If your products contain any SVHC above 0.1% by weight, you must submit a notification to ECHA's SCIP database before or when placing the product on the EU market. This ensures waste operators have information about hazardous substances in products. This has been mandatory since January 2021.

Safe use instructions for the article
SCIP notification number (generated upon submission)

Linking of sub-articles within complex objects in SCIP submission
Periodic review and update of SCIP notifications upon Candidate List changes

name: GBA Battery Passport (Voluntary)
description: The Global Battery Alliance offers a voluntary battery passport framework covering seven sustainability pillars: GHG emissions, human rights, child labour, biodiversity, forced labour, circular design, and indigenous peoples’ rights.
plainLanguage: You can voluntarily adopt the GBA Battery Passport to demonstrate sustainability leadership. It goes beyond EU requirements by covering broader topics like biodiversity and indigenous rights. It can help you prepare for EU regulatory compliance.
dataRequirements: GHG emissions data (per GBA GHG Rulebook)
Human rights due diligence
Child labour assessment
Biodiversity impact assessment
Circular design metrics

name: REACH -- SVHC Communication Duty (Art 33)
requirement: Communication of SVHC Information in Articles (Article 33)
description: Any supplier of an article containing a Candidate List substance (SVHC) in a concentration above 0.1% weight by weight must communicate sufficient information to allow safe use to the recipient of the article, including at minimum the name of the substance. Upon request from a consumer, the same information must be provided free of charge within 45 days. This obligation applies to all articles placed on the EU market.
plainLanguage: If your products contain any SVHC above 0.1% by weight, you must proactively inform your business customers (with at least the substance name) and respond to any consumer's request for this information within 45 days. This is already in effect and applies to all physical products.

timeline.label: Active (since REACH entered into force, 1 June 2007)

dataRequirements: Identification of all SVHCs present above 0.1% w/w (substance name, CAS number, EC number)
Concentration of each SVHC in the article (% w/w)
Location of SVHC within product (component, material, sub-assembly)
Safe use instructions for articles containing SVHCs

Supply chain communication records (downstream and upstream)
Current ECHA Candidate List screening (updated biannually)

name: REACH -- Authorisation for SVHC Use (Annex XIV)
requirement: Authorisation for Use of Annex XIV Substances (Articles 55-66)
description: Substances listed on REACH Annex XIV cannot be placed on the market or used after their sunset date unless an authorisation has been granted by the European Commission. Applicants must demonstrate that risks are adequately controlled or that socio-economic benefits outweigh the risks, and must analyse the availability of suitable alternatives. Currently approximately 60 substances are on Annex XIV with staggered sunset dates.
plainLanguage: If you use any substance listed on REACH Annex XIV in your manufacturing or products, you need a formal authorisation from the European Commission to continue using it after its sunset date. You must also investigate alternatives. This applies to substance users in the EU.
dataRequirements: Inventory of Annex XIV substances used in products or processes
Authorisation application or downstream user notification (per substance)
Analysis of alternatives (Art 62(4)(e))
Substitution plan with timeline where alternatives exist
Chemical safety report for authorised substances
Sunset date tracking per substance
Authorisation decision reference numbers
Downstream user notification to ECHA (Art 66)

name: REACH -- Substance Restrictions (Annex XVII)
requirement: Restrictions on Manufacture, Placing on Market and Use of Substances (Articles 67-73, Annex XVII)
description: REACH Annex XVII contains approximately 70 restriction entries covering specific substances or substance groups in specific uses. These include lead in consumer articles, cadmium in plastics and coatings, nickel in articles in direct skin contact, chromium VI in leather, azo dyes in textiles, PAHs in rubber/plastic components, phthalates (DEHP, DBP, BBP, DIBP) in plasticised materials, and many others. Manufacturers and importers must ensure products comply with all applicable Annex XVII restrictions.
plainLanguage: Your products must not exceed the substance limits set out in REACH Annex XVII. These include specific restrictions for lead, cadmium, nickel, chromium VI, certain dyes, PAHs, phthalates, and many other substances depending on your product type. This is already in effect.

timeline.label: Active (restrictions in force since 1 June 2009, continuously updated)

dataRequirements: Full bill of materials with substance-level composition data

PAH content in rubber/plastic components (Entry 50)

name: REACH -- PFAS Universal Restriction (Proposed)
requirement: Proposed Universal Restriction on Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS)
description: ECHA received a restriction proposal in February 2023 from five national authorities (Germany, Denmark, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden) to restrict the manufacture, placing on market, and use of approximately 10,000 PFAS substances. If adopted, this would be the broadest REACH restriction ever, affecting virtually every product category. ECHA's RAC and SEAC committees have been evaluating the proposal. Adoption expected 2025-2027, with use-specific transition periods of 18 months to 12+ years depending on the application.
plainLanguage: The EU is proposing a near-total ban on PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, also known as 'forever chemicals'). This would affect ~10,000 substances used in coatings, textiles, electronics, and many other products. If your products contain PFAS, start planning for alternatives now.

timeline.label: Expected adoption 2026-2027; transition periods vary by use

dataRequirements: Inventory of all PFAS-containing materials, components, and products
PFAS substance identification (CAS numbers, concentrations)
Assessment of PFAS function in each application
Alternatives analysis and substitution roadmap
Transition period applicability per product use category
Supplier engagement plan for PFAS elimination
Testing capability for total organic fluorine or targeted PFAS analysis
Product-category PFAS risk assessment (high risk: textiles, furniture, cookware; medium risk: electronics, construction; lower risk: batteries, iron/steel)
Total organic fluorine (TOF) screening results for products suspected of containing PFAS
PFAS-free alternatives documentation per application
ECHA/RAC opinion tracking per use-category for transition period planning

links.title: ECHA: Registry of Restriction Intentions -- PFAS

name: REACH -- Candidate List Monitoring
requirement: Ongoing Monitoring of ECHA Candidate List Updates (Article 59)
description: ECHA updates the Candidate List of SVHCs approximately twice per year (typically January and June). As of early 2025, the Candidate List contains approximately 240 substances. Each new addition immediately triggers Article 33 communication duties and SCIP notification obligations for articles containing the newly listed substance above 0.1% w/w. Companies must continuously monitor updates and re-screen their product portfolios.
plainLanguage: ECHA regularly adds new substances to the SVHC Candidate List (about twice a year). Each time a new substance is added, you must check whether it is present in your products above 0.1% by weight. If so, you immediately have new communication and SCIP notification duties.

timeline.label: Ongoing (biannual updates, typically January and June)

dataRequirements: Process for monitoring ECHA Candidate List updates (biannual)
Product portfolio re-screening procedure upon new additions
Full material declarations from suppliers covering current Candidate List
Gap analysis when new SVHCs are added (affected products, components, concentrations)
Updated SCIP notifications within reasonable timeframe of new listings
Updated Article 33 communication to supply chain recipients
Internal registry of substances approaching Candidate List inclusion (ECHA Registry of Intentions)

name: General Product Safety Regulation (GPSR)
requirement: General Safety, Traceability & Economic Operator Obligations (Articles 5-22)
description: The GPSR applies to consumer products placed on the EU market that are not fully covered by sector-specific harmonised legislation (lex specialis). It requires economic operators (manufacturers, importers, distributors, and online marketplaces) to ensure products are safe, maintain traceability through the supply chain, conduct internal risk analysis, cooperate with market surveillance authorities, and report dangerous products via the Safety Gate (RAPEX) system. Products covered by dedicated sector legislation (e.g., batteries, medical devices) may be partially or fully exempt where that legislation addresses the same safety aspects.
plainLanguage: If you sell consumer products in the EU, you must ensure they are safe and traceable. This applies when your products are sold to consumers (B2C) and are not fully covered by sector-specific safety rules. You need to keep records, conduct risk assessments, cooperate with authorities, and report dangerous products. Products with dedicated EU safety legislation (e.g., Battery Regulation) may be partially exempt.
dataRequirements: Batch or serial number or other traceability element
Consumer safety warnings in language of member state of sale
Contact point for market surveillance authorities
Corrective action and recall procedures
Identification of other economic operators in the supply chain
Incident and complaint records
Incident reporting procedure for Safety Gate (RAPEX)
Internal risk analysis documentation
Internal risk assessment documentation
Manufacturer and importer contact details on product or packaging
Manufacturer or authorised representative contact details
Online product listing safety information (for online sales)
Product identification (name, image, identifiers)
Product traceability data (manufacturer, importer, batch/serial number)
Product traceability information (manufacturer, importer, product identification)
Records of complaints and product recalls
Risk assessment records
Safety Gate notification records (where unsafe product identified)
Safety Gate/RAPEX notification capability
Safety test reports or certificates
Technical documentation demonstrating product safety
Technical documentation for product safety

name: CSDDD — Supply Chain Due Diligence
requirement: Human Rights and Environmental Due Diligence (Articles 5–11)
description: Large companies must identify, prevent, mitigate, and account for actual and potential adverse human rights and environmental impacts in their own operations and those of their direct and indirect business partners throughout the value chain. Companies must establish a due diligence policy, integrate it into management systems, maintain a grievance mechanism, and publicly communicate their approach.
plainLanguage: If your company meets the size thresholds (1,000+ employees AND €450M+ turnover for the final phase), you must implement a comprehensive due diligence process covering human rights and environmental risks across your entire value chain — from raw material sourcing through to final customers. This includes identifying risks, taking preventive and corrective action, and providing a complaints mechanism.

timeline.label: 26 July 2028 (>5000 emp, >€1.5B); phased to 2029–2030 (smaller tiers). Subject to Omnibus simplification — transposition deadline postponed to 26 July 2028

dataRequirements: Due diligence policy document (Art 5)
Adverse impact identification and assessment methodology (Art 6)
Supply chain risk mapping (own operations + direct and indirect partners)
Preventive and corrective action plans (Arts 7–8)
Remediation measures and processes (Art 9)
Grievance mechanism description and accessibility (Art 9)
Stakeholder engagement records (Arts 10–11)
Annual public report on due diligence activities and findings
Supply chain partner contractual assurances
Monitoring and verification procedures

name: CSDDD — Climate Transition Plan
description: In-scope companies must adopt and put into effect a climate transition plan to ensure that the business model and strategy are compatible with the transition to a sustainable economy and with the limiting of global warming to 1.5°C in line with the Paris Agreement. The plan must include time-bound emission reduction targets and identify key decarbonisation levers and investment needs.
plainLanguage: If your company falls under CSDDD, you must create and implement a climate transition plan setting out how you will contribute to limiting global warming to 1.5°C. The plan must include concrete emission reduction targets, key actions, and an investment plan for decarbonisation.

timeline.label: 26 July 2028 (>5000 emp, >€1.5B); phased to 2029–2030 (smaller tiers). Subject to Omnibus simplification — transposition deadline postponed to 26 July 2028

dataRequirements: Climate transition plan document (Art 15)
Time-bound GHG emission reduction targets (Scope 1, 2, and where appropriate Scope 3)
Key decarbonisation levers and actions
Investment and funding plan for transition
Role of offsets (if any) and their limitations
Explanation of alignment with Paris Agreement 1.5°C pathway
Annual progress reporting against targets
Board-level oversight documentation

name: CSRD -- Sustainability Reporting
description: Companies in scope of CSRD must report sustainability information according to the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS). IMPORTANT: The EU Omnibus simplification package (2025) has postponed application dates for Wave 2 (large non-NFRD companies) and subsequent waves by 2 years. Only Wave 1 companies (former NFRD entities — large public-interest entities with 500+ employees) are currently reporting (FY 2024). Wave 2 (all large companies) is now expected for FY 2027 instead of FY 2025. Listed SMEs are further postponed. Confirm your company's NFRD history to determine your actual reporting start date.
plainLanguage: If your company meets the CSRD size thresholds, you must include detailed sustainability information in your annual management report. HOWEVER: the EU has postponed the reporting start date for most companies by 2 years under the Omnibus package. Only companies that were already reporting under the old NFRD (large public-interest entities with 500+ employees) are currently required to report. For other large companies, reporting now starts from FY 2027 at the earliest. Check whether your company was previously under NFRD to determine your actual timeline.

timeline.label: FY 2024 (Wave 1: former NFRD entities only). Omnibus postponement: Wave 2 (all large) now FY 2027; listed SMEs FY 2028; non-EU >EUR150M FY 2030

_statusNote: Status 'active' applies only to Wave 1 (former NFRD entities). For most large companies, CSRD is effectively 'upcoming' due to Omnibus 2-year postponement. Confirm NFRD history.
dataRequirements: Double materiality assessment results (ESRS 1)
Governance structure and sustainability oversight (ESRS 2, GOV-1 to GOV-5)
Strategy and business model sustainability integration (ESRS 2, SBM-1 to SBM-3)
Sustainability-related targets and progress metrics (ESRS 2, MDR-T)
Sustainability policies across all material topics (ESRS 2, MDR-P)
Actions and resources allocated to sustainability (ESRS 2, MDR-A)
XHTML/XBRL digital tagging of sustainability disclosures (Art 29d)
Independent auditor limited assurance opinion (Art 34)
Consolidated group-level reporting (where applicable)
Value chain information where material (upstream and downstream)

name: Market Surveillance -- Economic Operator Obligations
requirement: Economic Operator Obligations for Products Sold on the EU Market (Articles 4-7)
description: Products subject to EU harmonised legislation that are placed on the EU market must have an economic operator established in the EU who is responsible for compliance tasks, including making the EU Declaration of Conformity and technical documentation available to authorities, cooperating with market surveillance authorities, and informing authorities when a product presents a risk. This applies to all CE-marked products.
plainLanguage: If you sell products on the EU market that fall under EU product safety or harmonisation legislation, there must be an EU-based economic operator (manufacturer, importer, authorised representative, or fulfilment service provider) who is responsible for keeping compliance documents ready and cooperating with authorities on request.
dataRequirements: EU Declaration of Conformity (available to authorities on request)
Technical documentation (available to authorities on request)
Contact details of EU-based responsible economic operator on product or packaging
Product traceability records (suppliers and recipients for 10 years)
Corrective action records and recall documentation
RAPEX/Safety Gate notification records (where applicable)
Cooperation log with market surveillance authorities
